Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Rechargeable Zn Metal Battery with Long Life and Low Cost
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to explore translation of a rechargeable zinc-metal battery for large-scale energy storage. Renewable but intermittent energy sources require cost-effective storage. The proposed battery essentially converts a primary alkaline battery to a rechargeable form with novel chemical components. This project will demonstrate the long cycle life of zinc-metal batteries under conditions amenable for applications such as backup power for data centers, grid-level needs, and household energy storage use. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop Zn-metal batteries in use-inspired battery configurations and cell dimensions. This project is to translate the fundamental understanding of Zinc-salt-based water-in-salt electrolytes that strengthen the inertness of both water molecules of the electrolytes and Zn metal anode. The proposed technology offers stable cycle life with excellent power output in an appropriate footprint. The project will advance the development of new electrolytes that greatly mitigate the hydrogen evolution reaction and eliminate dendrite formation on the Zn metal anode. The new electrolytes address the challenges of both anode and cathode, where the cathode capacity fading issues will be addressed.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF SBIR Phase I Award Number – 2012221  

NSF Program Manager – Dr. Anna Brady-Estevez 

Overview

GROTTHUSS’ Phase I effort has significantly advanced the state-of-the-art of Zn metal batteries. The primary success is having brought the Coulombic efficiency of Zn metal anode to the limits of 99.97%, which has readied GROTTHUSS’ Zn metal batteries with extended longevity comparable to Li-ion batteries. GROTTHUSS has devised the formulae of advanced aqueous electrolytes and made the selections of current collectors, the separator, and the cathode materials. The successes in Phase I have readied GROTTHUSS for testing of large prototype cells. GROTTHUSS has established connections with leading battery manufacturers, where these companies will be GROTTHUSS’ potential customers and investors. The goal of GROTTHUSS’ Phase II program is to finalize the battery product design in terms of form factors and choice of battery components to facilitate the low levelized energy cost of domestic manufacturing. The effort will meet the market need in the U.S. and around the globe for safe storage batteries.

Intellectual Merit

GROTTHUSS’ Phase I effort has transformed the reversibility of Zn metal anode. Before the project, the Coulombic efficiency of the Zn metal anode is well below 99% at a current density of 0.2 mA per square centimeter. At the current stage, GROTTHUSS has pushed the Coulombic efficiency to 99.97% at the same current density. Hydrogen evolution reaction between the Zn metal anode and the aqueous electrolyte has been eliminated. GROTTHUSS designed the proprietary electrolyte formula that forms robust solid-electrolyte interphase on the surface of the Zn metal anode that shields the Zn metal anode from water molecules. The electrolyte is also inherently more inert in its redox reactivity, which addresses the gassing problem of Zn metal batteries that have plagued this technology for decades. GROTTHUSS’ Phase I effort has also screened a great number of cathode materials, separators, and current collectors, and GROTTHUSS has arrived at the conclusions about which materials to use for the prototype pouch cells with larger form factors. Pouch cells are of low cost compared to cylindrical cells and can be packed into large modules. Prior to GROTTHUSS’ Phase I effort, it was generally believed that Zn batteries cannot adopt pouch cells due to the gasification of hydrogen evolution reaction. GROTTHUSS’ technology has squarely circumvented this obstacle for low-cost Zn metal battery pouch cells. The two key Objectives for GROTTHUSS’ Phase II is (1) to optimize the electrolyte, the electrodes, the separator, and current collectors to achieve the synergy of these battery components in large pouch cells; (2) and to bring up the energy density of Zn metal batteries closer to Li-ion batteries by identifying a new cathode material. By the end of Phase II program, GROTTHUSS will have demonstrated large prototype batteries with competitive energy densities and will earn the edge to enter the market of targeted applications.

Broader Impacts

Storage batteries must be non-flammable, which rules out the state-of-the-art of Li-ion batteries. Aqueous Zn metal batteries represent the most promising non-flammable candidate for new battery designs. However, Zn metal batteries are plagued by the consumption of Zn metal due to its reaction with the electrolyte during cycling. GROTTHUSS’ Phase I has addressed this challenge! The excellent performances now achieved and the low cost of Zn batteries, coupled with the increased safety factor will result in an unprecedented low levelized energy cost. The commercialization of this battery technology will be disruptive to the entire energy industry. The societal impacts of this battery technology will be immense, potentially being able to replace both lead acid and Li-ion batteries with a single, safe alternative and thus revolutionizing the energy storage domain.
